awd_titl_txt: Instrument Development: 4-D Near-Infrared Chemical Imaging Using Snapshot Tomography
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sung at University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) develops new instruments for 4-dimensional (4D) chemical imaging in the near-infrared (NIR) range. NIR hyperspectral imaging has been widely used for nondestructive quality inspection; however, existing methods cannot examine a specimen with a complicated internal structure or detect the chemical impurities buried deep inside a 3-D volume because the depth information is lost in the recorded 2-D projection images. Traditional approaches to 3-D tomographic imaging require a scanning mechanism, which significantly increases the data acquisition time and the complexity of an instrument. Professor Sung and his group is developing instruments using a technique called snapshot tomography, which can acquire the 3-D tomogram in a single snapshot. By incorporating various wavelength-scan strategies, the new instruments can acquire the 4-D hyperspectral data at a high speed and good spatial resolution. The instruments, once developed, could potentially impact many industries by allowing nondestructive quality inspection of pharmaceutical, chemical, petrochemical, or agricultural products.  Applications such as improving human health by detecting counterfeit medicines or being used in failure analysis of 3-D integrated-circuit chips in solar cells or micro-electro-mechanical system (MEMS) devices are envisioned. Professor Sung strives to provide training opportunities to undergraduate researchers and K-12 students, the future generation of scientists and engineers.  He also works on incorporating cutting-edge science into course materials and is actively engaged in many on-campus programs to recruit more women and minority students into his group.

Professor Sung is developing a 4D NIR absorption and refractive index imaging where a wavelength-scanning light source is combined with a snapshot tomography technique that is enabled by a micro-lens array and digital holography. A common-path design is incorporated to further increase the robustness to environmental vibrations and a spatial light modulator to actively compensate for the chromatic aberration. For 4-D NIR emission imaging, a tunable bandpass filter or Fourier transform spectroscopy is combined with another snapshot tomography technique for luminescence light. The theoretical frameworks to be developed is believed to extend the application of diffraction tomography to more general classes of absorbing specimens and increase the accuracy of emission tomography by including the wave nature and the partial coherence of light in the image formation and reconstruction models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have developed 4D (3D structure and 1D spectrum) chemical imaging instruments for microscopic specimens using the visible light (400-700 nm) and the near-infrared light (1100-1700 nm). Traditional approaches to 3D structural imaging require a scanning mechanism, which significantly increases the data acquisition time and the complexity. 4D imaging adds a wavelength-tuning mechanism to 3D structural imaging, and thus takes even longer and more complex. These disadvantages have prohibited adopting 4D chemical imaging in practice, despite the abundant information that the technique can provide. To overcome this limitation, we have developed snapshot optical tomography, which acquires the 3D structure of a specimen in a single snapshot using a micro-lens array (MLA). Snapshot optical tomography can be performed using three different contrast mechanisms: the absorption by chromophores in the specimen, the emission by various luminophores (e.g., fluorophores, luciferin/luciferase) in the specimen, and the phase alteration induced by the refractive index variation in the specimen.

To acquire a hyperspectral data cube, we have constructed a Fourier-transform spectroscopy (FTS) module in a cage system and using a piezo stage with nanometer precision. In comparison with filter-, prism-, or grating-based methods, FTS can provide higher spectral resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Combining snapshot optical tomography with the FTS module, we have developed a 4D visible and a 4D NIR tomography system. 4D imaging has been demonstrated first with fluorescent samples (fluorescent beads and pollen grains), then with absorbing samples (dyed polymer beads and red blood cells in different oxygenation states). The developed instruments can also be applied to microplastics, embryos, fibers, pharmaceutical powders, and other microscopic specimens.

Together with the instrument development, we have developed a theoretical model for the image formation in snapshot tomography. The theoretical model was built upon a wave-optics theory valid for a high-numerical-aperture objective lens. We have simplified it using the fact that the numerical aperture of each lenslet in the MLA is small. The developed theory has provided a forward image model in an explicit, closed form, which has been adopted in our fast-yet-accurate tomographic reconstruction algorithms for absorption- and emission-mode snapshot optical tomography. It has also allowed us to understand a trade-off between the resolution and the number of projection images acquired by the MLA, as well as a trade-off between the resolution and the field of view.

FTS is the gold standard method for infrared spectroscopy and also a preferred method when high spectral resolution is required, or the SNR is low. The requirement of a large sampling number is often considered as a major disadvantage of FTS. Using deep learning, we have demonstrated that the FTS sampling number can be reduced by 10 times to classify ten types of fluorescent beads, whose emission peaks span the wavelength range of 485?698 nm, and by 20 times to predict the fluorescence intensity in 3 color fluorescence imaging. This significant reduction in the sampling number is possible because deep learning bypasses the Fourier transform process and extracts the information directly from the raw interferogram. We have also demonstrated that, using deep learning, the He-Ne correction (traditionally used in FTS to compensate for the translation stage error and environmental vibrations) can be bypassed, eliminating several optical elements, and reducing the cost, size, and complexity of the FTS system.

This project has provided an opportunity to train researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) in various fields such as spectroscopy, hyperspectral imaging, optical tomography, and deep learning. In this project, seven graduate and two undergraduate researchers have been trained through the research, group meetings, and three independent courses (Light Scattering, Computerized Tomographic Imaging, and Deep Learning). The PI has modified two courses that he teaches at UWM to include the most recent advances made in this project. In addition to the lectures, he introduced three hands-on lab demonstrations, which were very well received by the students. The research results have hitherto been published in five peer-reviewed journals and presented at three national conferences. The results obtained with the developed instrument in ongoing research will be published in the future. Some of the technologies developed in this project have laid the groundwork for 3D imaging flow cytometry, a method that can record the 3D images of single cells in a flow configuration, and a realistic simulation of X-ray imaging at a human scale.
